arm_group.description: Patients having a BMI between 95-99% who are seen in the ambulatory surgery centers.
Patients having a BMI between 95-99% who are seen in the main operating rooms.
Patients having a BMI >99% who are seen in the main operating rooms.

brief_summary.textblock:
The investigators are concerned about anesthetizing obese children in outpatient locations
      in case they need prolonged stay, increased respiratory interventions, or need for
      post-operative narcotics. The investigators will be using a screening guideline to help us
      determine the higher risk child based on BMI and co-morbid conditions. The investigators
      will also be doing a retrospective chart review of 300 patients with BMI 95% and looking at
      various factors during the operative and post-operative period.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients 95% or over BMI having outpatient surgery.

intervention.description: Screening guideline to assess body mass index.

clinical_study.official_title: Have NCH Obesity Guidelines Made an Impact? Differences in Anesthetizing the Obese Child in Outpatient Sites Versus Main OR at NCH.

reference.citation: Smith HL, Meldrum DJ, Brennan LJ. Childhood obesity: a challenge for the anaesthetist? Paediatr Anaesth. 2002 Nov;12(9):750-61. Review.
Nafiu OO, Reynolds PI, Bamgbade OA, Tremper KK, Welch K, Kasa-Vubu JZ. Childhood body mass index and perioperative complications. Paediatr Anaesth. 2007 May;17(5):426-30.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of subjects with respiratory complications

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Retrospective
